contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox automobile | image =Oldsmobile Curved Dash Runabout 1904 2.jpg | name = Oldsmobile Runabout | manufacturer = [[Oldsmobile]] | production = 1901–1907<br />About 19000 built | predecessor = | successor = | class = Entry-level car | platform = | body_style = [[Runabout (car)|Runabout]] | engine = {{convert|95|cuin|cc|abbr=on}} horizontal one-cylinder<ref name="Period" /> | transmission = [[Planetary gear|Planetary]] 2-speed | wheelbase = | length = | width = | height = | weight = | aka = | related = | designer = }} [[File:In My Merry Oldsmobile a2701-1-72dpi.jpeg|right|thumb|238px|''[[In My Merry Oldsmobile]]'' songbook featuring an Oldsmobile Curved Dash automobile]] The gasoline powered '''Curved Dash Oldsmobile''' is credited as being the first [[mass-produced]] [[automobile]], meaning that it was built on an [[assembly line]] using [[interchangeable parts]]. It was introduced by the [[Oldsmobile]] company in 1901 and produced through 1907. 425{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}}<!--[[G.N. Georgano]], ''Cars: Early and Vintage, 1886-1930''. (London: Grange-Universal, 1985), says 400.--> examples were produced the first year, 2,500 in 1902, with over 19,000 built in all.<ref>[[G.N. Georgano]] ''Cars: Early and Vintage, 1886-1930''. (London: Grange-Universal, 1985)</ref> It was a [[runabout (car)|runabout]] model, could seat two passengers, and sold for [[USD|US$]]650. While competitive, due to high volume, and below the [[Ford]] US$850 "Doctor's Car",<ref>Clymer, Floyd. ''Treasury of Early American Automobiles, 1877-1925'' (New York: Bonanza Books, 1950), p.37.</ref> [[Western Tool Works (automobile company)|Western]] in 1905 produced the Gale Model A roadster at US$500, the [[Black Motor Company|Black]] went as low as $375,<ref>Clymer, p.61.</ref> and the [[Success Automobile Manufacturing Company|Success]] hit the amazingly low US$250.<ref>Clymer, p.32.</ref> The flat-mounted [[water-cooled]] single-cylinder engine, situated at the center of the car, produced {{convert|5|hp|kW|abbr=on}},<ref name="Period">{{cite book| last = Rogliatti| first = Gianni| editor = Cyril Posthumus| editor-link = Cyril Posthumus| title = Period Cars| year = 1973| publisher = Hamlyn| location = Feltham, Middlesex, UK| isbn = 0-600-33401-5| pages = 270–271}}</ref> relying on a brass [[gravity feed]] [[carburetor]]. The transmission was a semi-automatic design with two forward speeds and one reverse. The low-speed forward and reverse gear system are a [[planetary gear|planetary]] type (epicyclic). The car weighed {{Convert|850|lb|kg|abbr=on}} and used Concord springs. It had a top speed of 20 mph (32 km/h). The car’s success was partially by accident - in 1901 a fire destroyed a number of other models before they were approved for production, leaving the Curved Dash the only one intact.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.detnews.com/apps/history/index.php?id=28 |title=detnews.com | Michigan History |publisher=Apps.detnews.com |date=2000-03-08 |accessdate=2009-06-27}}</ref> ==Gallery== {{Commons category}} <gallery> File:Oldsmobile Curved Dash Runabout 1903 2.jpg|Oldsmobile Model R Curved Dash Runabout 1903 File:Oldsmobile Curved Dash Runabout 1903.jpg|Oldsmobile Model R Curved Dash Runabout 1903 File:Oldsmobile Curved Dash Runabout 1904 2.jpg|Oldsmobile Model 6C Curved Dash Runabout 1904 File:Oldsmobile Curved Dash Runabout 1904 3.jpg|Oldsmobile Model 6C Curved Dash Runabout 1904 File:Oldsmobile Curved Dash Runabout 1904.jpg|Oldsmobile Model 6C Curved Dash Runabout 1904 File:Oldsmobile Curved Dash Runabout 1905.jpg|Oldsmobile Model B Curved Dash Runabout 1905 </gallery> {{reflist}} ==Sources== * Clymer, Floyd. ''Treasury of Early American Automobiles, 1877-1925''. New York: Bonanza Books, 1950. * ''Frank Leslie's Popular Monthly'' (January, 1904) * [[G.N. Georgano]], G. N. ''Cars: Early and Vintage, 1886-1930''. London: Grange-Universal, 1985. ==External links== {{commons category|Oldsmobile Curved Dash}} *[http://oldsclub.org/ Oldsmobile Club of America] *[http://www.schs-museum.org/pictures/museum/earlytr.jpg 1905 Oldsmobile Image (Suffolk County(NY) Historical Society Museum)] *[http://books.google.com/books?id=nCEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA29&dq=popular+science+1951+From+Coast+To+Coast&hl=en&ei=kabCTJb-M4XFnAe4-fXyCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=popular%20science%201951%20From%20Coast%20To%20Coast&f=true ''From Coast To Coast In An Old Old Olds'', by Gardner Soule] large 1951 article on a 1904 Olds making a coast to coast trip with detailed photo of subject {{Oldsmobile}} [[Category:Oldsmobile vehicles|Curved Dash]] [[Category:Veteran vehicles]] [[Category:1900s automobiles]] [[Category:First automobile made by manufacturer]] [[Category:Vehicles introduced in 1901]]
